  - Trouble breathing, shortness of breath, or low oxygen
  - Chest pain, passing out, confused, very hard to wake
  - Very high fever (≥39°C / ≥102°F) that’s not coming down
  - New severe ear pain with drainage, or severe facial pain with swelling
- If your clinician already said you have pneumonia, bacterial ear infection, or another confirmed bacterial infection → take the prescribed antibiotic.

- You are pregnant, age ≥65, immunocompromised (chemo, transplant, HIV with low CD4), have severe heart/lung disease (eg, COPD, severe asthma, recent transplant), or have had recent hospitalization/IV antibiotics.
- If any of the above → call your clinician and ask whether you should start the antibiotic now or be seen for closer evaluation.

3) Possible bacterial features — consider starting antibiotic (or contact clinician)
Start antibiotics or call to reassess if you have either:
- Symptoms that have lasted >10 days without improvement (classic for bacterial sinusitis)
- OR severe onset: high fever (≥39°C/102°F) plus purulent nasal discharge or severe facial pain for ≥3–4 days
- OR worsening after initial improvement (you got better then got worse)
- OR signs of pneumonia: persistent high fever, productive cough with colored sputum, shortness of breath, or focal chest findings
- OR suspected strep throat (sudden severe sore throat, fever, swollen tender anterior neck nodes, white tonsillar exudate) — ask for a rapid strep test

4) Most common situation — do NOT take antibiotic yet; use watchful waiting
- If symptoms are mild (runny nose, sore throat, cough, low fever), started recently (<48–72 hours), and you are improving or stable:
  - Do not start the antibiotic.
  - Use supportive care: rest, fluids, acetaminophen/ibuprofen for fever/pain, saline nasal spray, throat lozenges, humidifier.
  - Re-evaluate after 48–72 hours: start antibiotic only if you’re worse or you meet the “possible bacterial” criteria above.

5) If you were given a “just in case” (delayed) prescription
- Only fill/start it if either:
  - You meet the “possible bacterial” criteria above, OR
  - You have not improved or have worsened after 48–72 hours (or 10 days for sinus symptoms).
- If you decide not to use it, destroy or return the prescription per clinic instructions.

6) Safety and questions to ask your clinician
- Do I actually have a suspected bacterial infection? If so, which one?
- What exact signs should make me start the antibiotic?
- What drug, dose, how long, and any alternatives if I’m allergic?
- What side effects to watch for (diarrhea, rash — stop and seek care for hives, swelling, breathing trouble)?
- When should I come back or call sooner?

Why be cautious: antibiotics won’t help viral infections, can cause side effects (diarrhea, allergic reactions, C. difficile), and promote antibiotic resistance.
